batches.overall_reasoning: mira is 20 months old with extraordinary pattern extraction, deep visual attention, and an empathic connection to characters. she memorizes books fast, pre-says words, and weaves characters into her play. these picks lean into those strengths: books she can predict, books she can look into deeply, and books with characters who'll become part of her world.

categories.name: pattern & prediction
categories.reasoning: mira extracts rules from single examples and loves pre-saying words. these books have strong repetitive structures she'll internalize fast - and the payoff is in the prediction, not just the reading.

items.title: dear zoo
items.author: rod campbell
items.why: lift-the-flap with a repeating rejection pattern: 'they sent me a... he was too tall! i sent him back.' every page follows the same structure, building to the perfect pet. she'll memorize the pattern within 2-3 reads and start pre-saying 'i sent him back!' - exactly what she does with the lion inside. the flaps add a physical prediction layer.

items.title: we're going on a bear hunt
items.author: michael rosen & helen oxenbury
items.why: repetitive refrain ('we can't go over it, we can't go under it, oh no! we've got to go through it!') is made for her pre-saying pattern. multi-sensory sounds (squelch squerch, swishy swashy, splash splosh) feed her auditory sensitivity. uses spatial words she already knows (under, over, through). and the fear-approach-retreat structure mirrors how she actually handles scary things.

categories.name: empathy & emotional connection
categories.reasoning: mira comforts babies she can't see, tracks who's present in a group, and runs back for one more huggie at bedtime. these books connect to that emotional depth - characters she'll care about and talk to.

items.title: owl babies
items.author: martin waddell & patrick benson
items.why: three baby owls (sarah, percy, bill) wait for their mother at night. bill keeps saying 'i want my mummy!' - a phrase she'll absolutely adopt. three distinct characters with different responses to worry (she tracks individuals in groups). the separation-reunion theme connects to her bedtime goodbye ritual. beautiful dark atmospheric illustrations with detail to explore.

items.title: guess how much i love you
items.author: sam mcbratney & anita jeram
items.why: parent and child compete in expressing love: 'i love you THIS much!' with escalating gestures (arms wide, as high as i can reach, to the moon and back). the escalation is a pattern she'll predict and extend. maps directly to her huggie/kissi rituals. simple, warm text she'll memorize. the 'to the moon and back' line will become a bedtime phrase.

categories.name: agency & imagination
categories.reasoning: mira is a self-starter who does things on her own terms. she's in a pretend play explosion - toasters, tea sets, shampoo bottles, birthday ceremonies. these books celebrate imagination and doing things your own way.

items.title: not a box
items.author: antoinette portis
items.why: a rabbit with a cardboard box. someone keeps asking 'why are you sitting in a box?' rabbit insists 'it's NOT a box!' - each page reveals what the rabbit imagines (race car, mountain, robot). minimal text, maximum imagination. she'll start saying 'it's not a [thing]!' about everyday objects during pretend play. celebrates exactly what she already does - seeing bottles as shampoo, drawing as bindi, boxes as anything.

items.title: stuck
items.author: oliver jeffers
items.why: she already loves oliver jeffers (here we are is an all-time classic). a kite gets stuck in a tree. floyd throws his shoe to get it down. the shoe gets stuck. he throws the other shoe, then a cat, a ladder, a whale, a house... escalating absurdity she can predict and narrate. problem-solving humor that connects to her peer trait - she'll have opinions about better solutions.

items.title: rosie's walk
items.author: pat hutchins
items.why: rosie the hen goes for a walk. the text only follows rosie. but in the pictures, a fox follows her and keeps getting into accidents (lands in pond, gets hit by rake, falls into haystack). the visual story is separate from the text - she'll narrate the fox's drama herself. rewards her deep-looking pattern: the real story is in the illustrations, not the words. short enough for 50+ re-reads, rich enough for new discoveries each time.
